_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers
Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

(40 CFR Part 68)



Facility, Stationary Sources & Regulated Substances Handled: Prevention

The chemical distribution facility at City of Industry, CA (14970 Don Julian Rd.) consists of a warehouse used to  ship, receive and store factory packaged regulated substances.  The warehouse was retrofitted in 2010 to meet Seismic risks.



General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

As an active member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors, we maintain a documented program, The Responsible Distribution Process. With a focus on safety and environmental control, it includes SOPs, personnel training/competency requirements; Emergency Response Plans.



Policy: It is the policy of Norman, Fox & Co. to promote Senior Management Commitment through policy, communications, and resources, to on-going improvements in chemical compounding, chemical distribution and safety. 



Responsible Distribution Code: I.A. 



Senior Management Commitment is expressed through its :



1. Membership in the National Association of Chemical Distributors and adoption of the Responsible Distribution Code of Management Practice as the foundation policies for company safety, health and environmental management. 



2. Participation in Responsible DistributionA® including:

-adoption of policies to support program implementation

-appointment of a Responsible Distribution Coordinator 

-participation in NACD sanctioned RDP third party audits

-implementation of internal audits, including initiation of corrective and preventive actions based on audit results

-development and implementation of procedures to support each Responsible Distribution Code of Management Practices. 



3. Budgeting to: 

-upgrade facilities & equipment

-provide for personnel training.



4. This commitment is documented through development and maintenance of:

-Responsible Distribution Process Procedures Manual, which meets requirements of a Calif

ornia Injury and Illness Protection Program (California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 3203)

-Quality Process Work Instructions in accordance with Food & Drug Administration requirements (21CFRA?211)

-Emergency Response Plan. 





Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Procedures in place for:



Cyclohexylamine            

1.Shipping/Receiving

2.Storage

3.Empty Container Pick Up

4.Preventive Maintenance

5.Emergency Response



Formaldehyde 37%        

1.Shipping/Receiving

2.Storage

3.Empty Container Pick Up

4.Preventive Maintenance

5.Emergency Response





Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidents in the past five years involving these chemicals.

This is a new facility with an occupancy start date for chemical storage of June 10,2010. 





Emergency Response Program

A  Consolidated Contingency Plan is filed with the Los Angeles Co. Fire Dept. in accordance with California regulations using CERS (California Environmental Reporting System).



A comprehensive Emergency Response Plan is maintained for use by the Facility Emergency Response authorities. 



All Operations personnel (i.e. warehouse, production, drivers) are trained and certified Hazwoper 1st Responder Operations level. Office personnel are in the process of training to Hazwoper 1st Responder Awareness Level   as it relates to this new location. These certificates are expected to be maintained. 



In response to a leak, spill, fire, explosion or airborne release, our Emergency Response Plan (tested annually)  is activated using dedicated emergency equipment (15 pre-placed Spill Kits), and calling in our Response Contractor as required. The objective in response is to: protect personnel; control or contain any release; decontamination and waste disposal. 



The facility responds to Incidental and Non-Incidental Releases. When the release is non-incidental, the Fire Dept. is notified. This also occurs for any fire situation.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety (Revised 2013)



1

.    An internal audit of general  operating practices was begun during February, 2013, with expected completion by December 31, 2013. A Compliance Audit was conducted during May & June 2013 with audit findings issued to management in June 2013.

2. Refer to most current issue of Improvement Log for list of findings and the status of corrective and preventive actions.
